cards.contribution: Discovered the alpha helix structure of proteins and defined the nature of the chemical bond
The woman behind the equation
The Architect of Bioenergy
Developed Gleevec (imatinib), first targeted cancer therapy for CML
John Hardy identified the first genetic mutation causing Alzheimer?s disease and proposed the amyloid cascade hypothesis, transforming how scientists understand and target neurodegeneration.

Kiyoshi Nagai pioneered the structural biology of the spliceosome, transforming our understanding of gene expression by proving through atomic-resolution imaging that this massive molecular machine is a dynamic, RNA-driven ribozyme.
Engaging with diverse perspectives is essential for fostering innovation and driving meaningful progress.

G. Marius Clore's primary contribution was the development of multidimensional NMR spectroscopy techniques, which allowed scientists for the first time to determine the high-resolution 3D structures of large proteins and nucleic acids directly in a liquid solution.
She discovered t-loop structure and the sheltering complex, proving the telomeres protect the chromosomes ends by tucking away a sailor's splice.

Dieter S?ll fundamentally expanded our understanding of the "universal" genetic code by discovering the indirect pathways organisms use to synthesize proteins and validating the existence of the 21st amino acid, Selenocysteine.

Martin Karplus revolutionized the field of biochemistry by developing multiscale models and molecular dynamics simulations that transformed our understanding of proteins from static "brass models" into dynamic entities governed by "jigglings and wigglings".
Master of DNA Untangling

Hugo Theorell revolutionized enzymology by being the first to split the "yellow enzyme" into its two essential parts?a protein and a vitamin-derived cofactor?thereby revealing the chemical mechanism of how enzymes facilitate cellular respiration.

Richard Willst?tter pioneered the application of rigorous organic chemistry to biological problems, fundamentally reshaping biochemistry by determining the chemical structures of plant pigments, most significantly revealing the magnesium-porphyrin core of chlorophyll.
Ruth Sager shattered the "nuclear monopoly" by discovering non-Mendelian inheritance in Chlamydomonas, proving for the first time that genetic material exists outside the cell nucleus.

Meyerhof revealed that muscle energy metabolism is a cyclical and thermodynamically coupled process, and it displayed how lactic acid that is produced without oxygen will later be recycled back into glycogen by means of energy from oxygen consumption.
She discovered the radioactive elements polonium and radium, fundamentally changing our understanding of atomic science and medical treatment.
Solved the first atomic structure of transfer RNA (tRNA), revealing how the genetic code is physically translated into proteins.
Jewel Plummer Cobb advanced cancer biology through groundbreaking melanoma research while transforming higher education by expanding access and equity for underrepresented scientists.
"He discovered HIF-1, the molecular switch that enables cells to sense low oxygen levels and activate the genes necessary for survival."
He discovered the intracellular sensor NOD2, establishing the first genetic link between the innate immune system's detection of bacteria and Crohn?s disease.

Helmut Beinert revealed the hidden role of iron?sulfur clusters in metabolism by identifying the ?impossible? g = 1.94 EPR signal, transforming how scientists understand electron transfer and catalysis in enzymes.

Efraim Racker pioneered the field of bioenergetics by isolating the F1 ATPase subunit and using it to reconstitute a functional energy-producing system, proving that life?s fuel is generated by a molecular motor.

Noboru Mizushima?s primary contribution was the biochemical characterization of the Atg12 and LC3 conjugation systems, which provided the first molecular explanation for how autophagosomes?the cell?s recycling machinery?are physically constructed and marked in mammals.

Heinrich Matthaei?s primary contribution was the conception and execution of Experiment 27Q, which successfully decoded the first "word" of the genetic language by proving that the RNA sequence poly-U directs the synthesis of the amino acid phenylalanine.

Tu Youyou isolated the heat-sensitive compound artemisinin from sweet wormwood using a low-temperature extraction method inspired by ancient texts, creating a breakthrough treatment that has saved millions of lives from malaria.

Kristala L. Jones Prather transformed modern biochemistry by engineering microbes into efficient chemical factories, enabling sustainable production of valuable compounds through synthetic metabolic pathways.

Dagmar Ringe transformed structural biochemistry by proving that enzymes are dynamic, ?breathing? machines, discovering the protein glass transition and enabling scientists to freeze and visualize catalytic reactions in motion.
Developed yeast artificial chromosome?based physical maps of human chromosomes that laid the foundation for the Human Genome Project and enabled rapid discovery of disease-causing genes.

Patrick Hsu pioneered next-generation CRISPR technologies?extending gene editing from DNA to RNA and programmable genome rearrangement?fundamentally expanding how scientists can read, write, and reprogram genetic information.

Suzanna Lewis transformed modern genomics by co-founding the Gene Ontology Consortium and developing the informatics standards necessary to translate massive amounts of raw DNA sequence data into a universally understood language of biological function.
Krebs was a pioneer scientist in the study of cellular respiration, a biochemical process in living cells that extracts ATP from food and oxygen.

Dennis Selkoe?s most significant contribution is his pioneering formulation of the amyloid cascade hypothesis, which posits that the accumulation of amyloid-beta protein in the brain is the primary trigger for Alzheimer's disease pathology.
Emil L. Smith helped found molecular evolution by showing that protein amino-acid sequences preserve a record of evolutionary relationships across species.
Feodor Lynen was a German biochemist who made foundational contributions to our understanding of metabolism and lipid synthesis, earning the 1964 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine.
Thomas Burr Osborne transformed biochemistry by proving that proteins are chemically distinct molecules whose specific amino acid compositions determine their nutritional and biological value.

Tom Maniatis revolutionized molecular biology by pioneering cDNA cloning techniques and co-authoring the definitive laboratory manual, "Molecular Cloning," which transformed gene manipulation from an "occult" art into a standardized global practice.

Maria Jasin demonstrated that creating a targeted DNA double-strand break activates homologous recombination in mammalian cells, a discovery that made precise gene editing?and ultimately CRISPR?possible.
